author: Andrej Simon
title: Schulbarometer: Verschlafen Deutschlands Lehrer die KI-Revolution?
text:
Schulbarometer: Verschlafen Deutschlands Lehrer die KI-Revolution?
Deutsche Lehrer tun sich schwer mit KI. Laut dem aktuellen Schulbarometer f√ºhlen sich 62 Prozent im Umgang damit unsicher. Scheitert die digitale Revolution an den Schulen?
Lehrer und Lehrerinnen tun sich schwer mit technischen Neuerungen. Dass sie da im Vergleich zu ihren Sch√ºlern nachhinken, ist schon lange Stoff f√ºr s√ºffisante Bemerkungen oder harte Kritik.
In der aktuell erscheinenden, von der Robert Bosch Stiftung ver√∂ffentlichten Forschungsarbeit "Deutsches Schulbarometer 2025" wird ersichtlich, dass die Lehrerschaft auch bei der neuesten hei√ü angepriesenen digitalen Revolution, dem Einsatz von KI, z√∂gern und zur Skepsis neigen.
Unsicherheit dominiert: Nur wenige Lehrkr√§fte nutzen KI regelm√§√üig
Lehrkr√§fte in Deutschland nutzen demnach KI-Tools wie ChatGPT in ihrem Berufsalltag nur eingeschr√§nkt. Die repr√§sentative Befragung von 1.540 Lehrkr√§ften im November und Dezember 2024 ergab, dass sich 62 Prozent im Umgang mit KI-Anwendungen unsicher oder sehr unsicher f√ºhlen. Einzig sechs Prozent sch√§tzen sich als sehr sicher ein.
Dabei zeigt sich beim Lehrk√∂rper, was allenthalben zu beobachten ist: Diejenigen, die mit KI arbeiten ‚Äì bei den Lehrkr√§ften sind es elf Prozent "mehrmals pro Woche oder t√§glich" KI-Tools verwenden, h√§ufiger sind es j√ºngere M√§nner ‚Äì haben ein positiveres Bild.
Lehrkr√§fte, die selbst KI nutzen, bewerten die Folgen zwar etwas positiver als ihre Kollegen ohne KI-Erfahrung. Doch auch bei ihnen √ºberwiegt die Skepsis. Um KI gewinnbringend im Unterricht einzusetzen, w√ºnschen sich viele Lehrkr√§fte gezielte Fortbildungen - insbesondere zur KI-gest√ºtzten Unterrichtsgestaltung (54 Prozent) und zu Methoden der Quellenbewertung (52 Prozent).
Viel Planung, wenig Kontrolle: KI bleibt im Unterricht Randerscheinung
Eingesetzt wird die Technologie vor allem f√ºr die Erstellung von Aufgaben (58 Prozent) und die Unterrichtsplanung (56 Prozent). Deutlich seltener kommt KI bei Leistungskontrollen (34 Prozent) und f√ºr individualisierte Lernangebote (28 Prozent) zum Einsatz.
F√ºr die Bewertung von Sch√ºleraufgaben (6 Prozent) oder die Analyse von Lernverlaufsdaten (3 Prozent) spielt KI bisher kaum eine Rolle.
In der Gesamtheit stehen die Lehrer dem KI-Einsatz im Unterricht √ºberwiegend skeptisch gegen√ºber. Mehr als 60 Prozent bef√ºrchten vor allem negative Auswirkungen auf die sozialen und kommunikativen F√§higkeiten sowie das kritische Denken der Sch√ºlerinnen und Sch√ºler.
Chancen sehen viele Lehrkr√§fte hingegen bei der gezielten F√∂rderung einzelner Lernender (57 Prozent) und mit Blick auf mehr Chancengerechtigkeit (29 Prozent).
KI als Lesehilfe? Mit kritisch geschultem Blick nutzbar
Das viel diskutierte Riesengel√§nde KI ist jedoch, worauf etwa ein detaillierter, mit kritischen Einw√§nden und Unterschiedlichkeiten arbeitender Erfahrungsbericht im US-Magazin The New Yorker, so wichtig und vital kritische Einw√§nde sind, mit eing√§ngigen Einstellungen wie "Hier verlernt ihr das Lesen und besonders das kritische Lesen" nicht wirklich fruchtbar zu bearbeiten.
Die KI kann als Hilfstool f√ºr die Lekt√ºre eingesetzt werden ‚Äì vorausgesetzt, dass den Sch√ºlern kritisches und vor allem wortgenaues Lesen beigebracht wird, wie dies etwa beim √úbersetzen von griechischen und lateinischen Texten unterrichtet wird. Um die Quintessenz grob zusammenzufassen: Die KI kann dabei helfen, mit gr√∂√üeren Textmengen umzugehen.
Sie kann Texte zusammenfassen, vereinfachen und verbinden ‚Äì und kann somit Beschr√§nkungen wie Zeit, Umfang und Verst√§ndnisschwierigkeiten aufheben. Allerdings braucht es dazu kompetente Nutzer, die etwa wissen, wo sich Fehler verbergen k√∂nnen und dass Stichproben bei den Quellen unabdingbar sind. Und man muss die Ergebnisse einordnen k√∂nnen.
Gesellschaftliche Zuwendung f√ºr den Nachwuchs fehlt
Dazu braucht es eine Lehrerschaft mit einem entsprechenden K√∂nnen. Allerdings sind derzeit daf√ºr die Bedingungen nicht gegeben. Deutschlands Lehrerinnen und Lehrer sind am Limit. Sie stehen aber vor immensen Herausforderungen. Doch im Bundeshaushalt fehlt das Geld f√ºr dringend n√∂tige Investitionen in Bildung. Stattdessen dominieren Ausgaben f√ºr Renten und R√ºstung.
Das aktuelle Deutsche Schulbarometer der Robert Bosch Stiftung zeigt auch: 42 Prozent der Befragten nennen das Verhalten der Sch√ºler als gr√∂√üte Herausforderung im Berufsalltag ‚Äì Tendenz stark steigend. Auch hohe Arbeitsbelastung und Zeitmangel setzen den P√§dagogen zu.
Kein Wunder, denn die Rahmenbedingungen an deutschen Schulen sind oft desolat. Viele Schulgeb√§ude sind marode, die sanit√§ren Anlagen eine Zumutung. F√ºr Kinder ist Schule heute h√§ufig kein Ort des Wohlf√ºhlens mehr. Jedes dritte Grundschulkind hat das Gef√ºhl, keinem einzigen Erwachsenen an der Schule wirklich wichtig zu sein.
Doch nicht nur baulich, auch gesellschaftlich stehen Schulen und Lehrkr√§fte vor wachsenden Problemen. Jedes siebte Kind in Deutschland gilt heute als armutsgef√§hrdet. Viele sind vom gesellschaftlichen Leben ausgeschlossen, Bildung wird in √§rmeren Familien seltener "vererbt".
Alles, was in unserer Gesellschaft schiefl√§uft, bekommen Kinder und Jugendliche besonders heftig zu sp√ºren ‚Äì und damit auch ihre Lehrerinnen und Lehrer.
Die Ursachen daf√ºr sind vielschichtig, haben aber eine gemeinsame Wurzel: chronische Unterfinanzierung. Im Bundeshaushalt fehlt schlicht das Geld, um die Probleme an der Wurzel zu packen. Stattdessen frisst der demografische Wandel die Zukunft auf. Schon heute flie√üt jeder vierte Euro des Bundeshaushalts in Rentenzahlungen ‚Äì Tendenz steigend.
Zusammen mit explodierenden R√ºstungsausgaben angesichts des Ukraine-Krieges bleibt da, wie die SZ dieser Tage eindr√ºcklich vor Augen f√ºhrte ‚Äì Untertitel: "So sehr wir Kinder lieben, gesellschaftlich sind sie uns vollkommen egal" ‚Äì, kaum Spielraum f√ºr Investitionen in Kinder und Bildung.

author: redacao@odia.com.br (Renata Cristiane)
title: Firjan SENAI inaugura unidades m√≥veis com cursos profissionalizantes em Cabo Frio
text:
Firjan SENAI inaugura unidades m√≥veis com cursos profissionalizantes em Cabo FrioDivulga√ß√£o
A iniciativa, que faz parte do planejamento da federa√ß√£o para a expans√£o dos servi√ßos pela Regi√£o dos Lagos, atende a uma das principais demandas locais, que √© garantir a oferta de cursos para promover a qualifica√ß√£o de m√£o de obra. ‚ÄúConseguimos trazer para esse espa√ßo duas unidades m√≥veis da maior import√¢ncia: uma de panifica√ß√£o, que √© um setor com grande demanda de m√£o de obra qualificada em todo o Brasil e a outra de Inform√°tica, tamb√©m de grande relev√¢ncia para a forma√ß√£o em TI. Essa √© uma oportunidade √∫nica para esses alunos que, paralelo √† educa√ß√£o regular, ter√£o uma profissionaliza√ß√£o, com o certificado do SENAI, de alto valor e empregabilidade no mercado‚Äù, destacou o 1¬∫ vice-presidente da Firjan, Luiz C√©sio Caetano, que inaugurou as instala√ß√µes ao lado da superintendente de Projetos Especiais da Secretaria de Estado de Educa√ß√£o, Cristina Silveira.
As unidades m√≥veis oferecer√£o capacita√ß√£o profissional para os alunos da escola e moradores das comunidades do entorno, que ter√£o a oportunidade de ter forma√ß√£o t√©cnica nos cursos de Operador de Computador, Assistente Administrativo, Assistente de Log√≠stica, Padeiro e Confeiteiro. ‚ÄúEssa √© uma oportunidade incr√≠vel para a mobilidade social. Para o engrandecimento e fortalecimento da nossa economia regional e gera√ß√£o de renda. Estamos entregando essas unidades para promover a gera√ß√£o de emprego e renda para a Regi√£o dos Lagos‚Äù, enfatizou o presidente da Firjan Leste Fluminense, Ricardo Fernando Guadagnin.
O evento contou ainda com a participa√ß√£o do presidente do Sindicato da Ind√∫stria de Panifica√ß√£o de Niter√≥i e Regi√£o (Sindpanific), S√©rgio Bousquet, que enfatizou a necessidade de investimento na forma√ß√£o profissional para o setor. ‚ÄúSempre buscamos atrair os jovens para esse aprendizado que vai melhorar a qualidade dos profissionais para o mercado‚Äù, complementou Bousquet.
Cursos oferecem forma√ß√£o para jovens e adultos da regi√£o
Com as primeiras turmas que come√ßaram as aulas nesta quarta-feira, as unidades m√≥veis j√° atendem 83 alunos que ser√£o capacitados para atua√ß√£o profissional. ‚ÄúO dia de hoje marca a concretiza√ß√£o dessa parceria com a Firjan. Esse √© um momento importante para os alunos que ter√£o suas vidas transformadas com esses cursos, oferecendo oportunidade de se tornarem profissionais qualificados‚Äù, destacou a diretora do Col√©gio Estadual Miguel Couto, Stef√¢nia Antunes.
Al√©m de estudantes da escola, entre os inscritos para os cursos, h√° jovens e adultos da comunidade local, que buscam uma primeira forma√ß√£o t√©cnica, conhecimento para uma segunda ocupa√ß√£o e at√© mesmo, mudar de profiss√£o. Esse √© o caso da professora de Filosofia, Silvia Helena Cardoso, que aos 52 anos de idade descobriu na panifica√ß√£o uma nova paix√£o, que aos poucos vem deixando de ser apenas um hobby e se tornando uma fonte de renda. Ao perceber a necessidade de ampliar os conhecimentos, decidiu aproveitar a oportunidade e se juntar aos alunos para se especializar.
‚ÄúSempre gostei de fazer p√£es e bolos. Fazia para fam√≠lia, amigos e aos poucos comecei a receber encomendas, o que foi me motivando. Senti a necessidade de aprender mais, me especializar e surgiu essa grande oportunidade‚Äù, conta Silvia que considera um desafio voltar √†s salas de aula para uma nova capacita√ß√£o. ‚Äú√â diferente dos cursos r√°pidos, ser√£o tr√™s meses de aulas di√°rias. √â uma adapta√ß√£o, mas estou muito animada, pois fazer p√£o √© uma grande paix√£o. O p√£o para mim √© uma forma de levar amor para as pessoas‚Äù, complementou a aluna, que pretende se especializar ainda na produ√ß√£o de p√£es com fermenta√ß√£o natural.
Novas turmas ser√£o abertas no m√™s de junho. Os interessados j√° podem fazer o cadastro reserva para as pr√≥ximas vagas. As inscri√ß√µes s√£o feitas de forma presencial, na unidade m√≥vel.

author: Paulo Pinto
title: Portugal-Cro√°cia, 2-1 Bruno Fernandes: ¬´Cr√≥acia tem muita qualidade¬ª | Abola.pt
text:
M√©dio destaca a vit√≥ria e real√ßa o valor do advers√°rio
Bruno Fernandes enalteceu a vit√≥ria de Portugal , apesar do sofrimento que a equipa sentiu na reta final. ¬´Nunca queremos sofrer, √© um facto, mas defront√°mos uma Cro√°cia de qualidade. Vimos o que eles fizeram no Europeu com bons resultados, o jogo com a Espanha foi enganador. Fomos competentes na primeira parte, entr√°mos bem na segunda parte, sobretudo nos primeiros 15 minutos, mas depois acab√°mos por baixar demasiado as linhas, demos posse de bola ao advers√°rio, mas soubemos defender bem a baliza, o que √© importante¬ª, disse na flash-interview da RTP.
Interpelado sobre os 900 golos apontados por Cristiano Ronaldo , o m√©dio de Portugal destacou o feito: ¬´N√≥s acab√°mos por parar de contar os golos, ele n√£o. Bateu mais um recorde, um recorde para Portugal e mais uma vez eleva o nome de Portugal a um patamar enorme. J√° n√£o h√° palavras¬ª, elogiou, deixando em aberto a possibilidade de o capit√£o estar tamb√©m no Campeonato do Mundo de 2026. ¬´A decis√£o √© dele, depende se sentir bem, num n√≠vel alto e √© capaz de chegar com grande n√≠vel a essa competi√ß√£o. Mas cabe-lhe a ele decidir¬ª, refor√ßou.

author: Euheniia Martyniuk
title: 10 Ukrainian children rescued from Russian occupation - Euromaidan Press
text: Ten Ukrainian children have been returned to Ukraine from Russian-occupied territories, the organization Save Ukraine reported. 10 üá∫üá¶ children have been returned to Ukraine from Russian-occupied üá∫üá¶ territories. The children report that the occupiers forced them to write letters and draw pictures for Russian soldiers who invaded üá∫üá¶, and sing the Russian national anthem. üìπ [https://t.co/0lT60ojvu5] [pic.twitter.com/Pu5vlSx7wQ] ‚Äî Euromaidan Press (@EuromaidanPress) [March 8, 2024] ‚ÄúUnder the occupier‚Äôs rule, our children are deprived of any rights and a normal, happy childhood. Therefore, there is no time to hesitate. To date, our organization has already rescued 261 children from Russia and the occupied territories,‚Äù the founder of Save Ukraine and former Presidential Commissioner for Children‚Äôs Rights in Ukraine, Mykola Kuleba [wrote]on Telegram. According to him, children in the occupied territories were forced to attend Russian schools, listen to and sing the Russian anthem, and write letters and draw pictures for the Russian soldiers who invaded Ukraine. As of February 2023, Ukraine [confirmed](https://childrenofwar.gov.ua/) the illegal deportation of 19,546 children. However, in reality, the number is likely much higher. Returning the children is extremely difficult, as the Russians often place them with foster families, changing their names and surnames. On 17 March 2023, the International Criminal Court in The Hague issued an arrest warrant for Russian President Vladimir Putin and Russian Commissioner for Children‚Äôs Affairs Maria Lvova-Belova. They are suspected of illegally deporting Ukrainian children from occupied territories to Russia. In July 2023, the Office of the Prosecutor General of Ukraine launched an investigation into the Belarusian Red Cross‚Äôs involvement in the deportation of Ukrainian children. Read more:

author: @prokerala
title: Serbian Parliament approves new govt led by Djuro Macut
text:
Belgrade, April 17 : The National Assembly of Serbia has elected a new government led by endocrinologist Djuro Macut.
A total of 153 members of Parliament voted on Wednesday in favour, 46 opposed, while 51 lawmakers were absent from the session.
The new Cabinet will comprise 31 members, Xinhua news agency reported.
Macut presented his government's programme and cabinet lineup on Tuesday, the first day of the special session of the National Assembly, outlining the key priorities of his administration.
Macut emphasised that his government would focus on domestic stabilisation and strategic foreign policy.
In response to ongoing youth-led protests and institutional disruptions, he pledged to uphold the rule of law and encourage open dialogue while safeguarding the rights of all citizens.
"Protests and expressions of discontent are natural for the youth," Macut said, "but blockades and the denial of others' rights to work, study, or live normally are unacceptable."
He announced the formation of a Council for Youth and Talents, which he will personally oversee.
The council aims to nurture young talent and harness their potential for the country's development.
On international affairs, Macut reaffirmed Serbia's sovereign and balanced approach.
While underscoring Serbia's commitment to the European Union (EU) accession process, he emphasised the country's independence in policymaking.
"Serbia does not approach the EU from a position of pleading, but from one of conviction. This relationship is a partnership founded on mutual respect, not asymmetry," he said.
He also stressed that domestic reforms are guided by national priorities rather than external demands.
"Our reforms are not a response to EU requirements. They are a response to the needs of our citizens," Macut added.
He also reaffirmed Serbia's dedication to broad international cooperation, saying that the country will "extend hands of cooperation to all".
Macut also addressed the Kosovo issue, calling it the highest national priority.
"We do not abandon our principles, but we do not reject dialogue. Peace is impossible without justice," he asserted.
Macut's nomination follows the resignation of former Prime Minister Milos Vucevic, who stepped down on January 28 amid mounting tensions following the deadly canopy collapse at the Novi Sad railway station in November 2024, which resulted in 16 fatalities.
The National Assembly officially confirmed Vucevic's resignation on March 19.
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->corporate governance and csr

author: Jordan Smith
title: GOP States Double Down on Fighting Medication Abortion After Supreme Court Keeps It Legal
text: In a unanimous ruling, the U.S. Supreme Court dismissed a challenge to the Food and Drug Administration‚Äôs 24-year-old approval of mifepristone, a common gynecological drug also used for medication abortion, ruling that the plaintiffs did not have legal standing to bring the suit in the first place. The ruling keeps mifepristone legal across the country ‚Äî at least for now. Under the Constitution, a plaintiff must be suffering some concrete injury to bring a federal lawsuit. In the mifepristone case ‚Äî FDA v. Alliance for Hippocratic Medicine ‚Äî the suit was brought by a collection of anti-abortion advocates, some of them doctors, who neither provide abortion care nor prescribe mifepristone. Nonetheless, they claimed that somehow, someday they may be forced to treat a patient suffering complications from taking mifepristone, which they said granted them the right to sue. The Supreme Court didn‚Äôt buy it. ‚ÄúThe plaintiffs do not prescribe or use mifepristone,‚Äù and the FDA approval doesn‚Äôt require them to do so, Justice Brett Kavanaugh wrote for the court. ‚ÄúRather, the plaintiffs want FDA to make mifepristone more difficult for other doctors to prescribe and for pregnant women to obtain.‚Äù Their desire to make the drug ‚Äúless available for others does not establish standing to sue.‚Äù The plaintiffs have long made the demonstrably false claim that mifepristone is frighteningly unsafe ‚Äî indeed, research making this claim was recently retracted by its publisher. Kavanaugh‚Äôs opinion seems to acknowledge what mainstream medicine and science have said about those claims: that mifepristone is safe, and there is no evidence that the FDA‚Äôs actions have led to increased safety issues or drug complications. Although the court made quick work of dismantling the Alliance‚Äôs claims, the future legal status of mifepristone is most certainly still in the crosshairs. In January, the states of Missouri, Kansas, and Idaho sought to intervene in the Alliance lawsuit, arguing that they have standing to sue because of their ‚Äúquasi-sovereign interest‚Äù in protecting the ‚Äúhealth and welfare of women and girls in their states‚Äù against the dangers of mifepristone so recklessly ignored by the FDA. Their effort to join in the legal action before the Supreme Court was denied, but their efforts at intervention are still alive in the lower courts. In statements just after the Supreme Court‚Äôs Thursday morning ruling, the attorneys general of Kansas and Missouri vowed to press their case. ‚ÄúWe are moving forward undeterred with our litigation to protect both women and their unborn children,‚Äù Missouri Attorney General Andrew Bailey said. And Idaho is fighting to roll back abortion access in other ways as well. Still outstanding from the Supreme Court this term is a ruling in another consequential case ‚Äî Idaho v. United States ‚Äî where the state is challenging long-standing federal law that requires hospitals to provide whatever emergency medical treatment is necessary to stabilize a patient, including abortion. That opinion is expected later this month. A Cynical Endeavor Mifepristone is the first drug in the standard two-medication abortion protocol. The FDA approved the drug in 2000 for use in early pregnancy termination. Mifepristone, which blocks the hormone progesterone (needed to maintain pregnancy) and softens the uterine lining, is taken first. The second drug, misoprostol, is taken 24 to 48 hours later and causes the uterus to contract, expelling the pregnancy. Medication abortion accounted for just 5 percent of abortions in 2001 and has since grown ‚Äî particularly in the wake of the Supreme Court‚Äôs 2022 Dobbs decision ‚Äî and now accounts for more than 60 percent of all abortions in the U.S. The protocol is also commonly used in miscarriage management. Over the years, the FDA has loosened restrictions around mifepristone ‚Äî including increasing the window for its use up to 10 weeks into pregnancy and doing away with a requirement that doctors dispense the drug in person (after all, there is no such requirement for dispensing misoprostol, which actually causes the abortion, and is taken later, at the time and place of the patient‚Äôs choosing). The FDA subsequently expanded access by allowing mail-order and brick-and-mortar pharmacies to dispense mifepristone to patients with a prescription in states where abortion is legal. The anti-abortion groups at the heart of the Alliance lawsuit didn‚Äôt like any of these developments and have long claimed ‚Äî devoid of any scientific backing ‚Äî that mifepristone is a uniquely dangerous drug and instead of being liberalized should be banned altogether. From the jump, the Alliance suit was a cynical, propagandistic endeavor . The Alliance is an umbrella organization made up of the American Association of Pro-Life Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the Christian Medical & Dental Association, the American College of Pediatricians, the Catholic Medical Association, and the Coptic Medical Association of North America. The members of these five well-known affinity groups have long been vocal about their anti-abortion views. The Alliance itself, however, is new: It incorporated in Texas‚Äôs Panhandle just three months before filing its lawsuit there ‚Äî an obvious ploy to draw federal Judge Matthew Kacsmaryk, a far-right darlin g, who is the lone judge in Amarillo tasked with hearing cases filed in the area. Kacsmaryk did not disappoint: In a raving opinion lifted from the pages of an anti-abortion talking-point glossary, he said the groups and their individual plaintiff doctors had the right to sue, and he issued a sweeping nationwide injunction that would block anyone, anywhere from using mifepristone for any reason. The federal government appealed to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which ultimately disagreed that mifepristone should be banned altogether, but did block the FDA‚Äôs more recent moves to increase its availability. In other words, the appeals court ruled that mifepristone could only be available under the most stringent of rules, rolling back the widely accepted medical standard of care. The FDA again appealed to the Supreme Court, which heard oral arguments in the case in March. Dubious Arguments Before the court, Erin Hawley, a lawyer with the far-right Alliance Defending Freedom , which represents the Alliance for Hippocratic Medicine, struggled to present a cogent argument for why her clients had standing to sue. The gist of it went something like this: Mifepristone is so wildly dangerous that patients suffering complications are going to be flooding medical facilities and inundating providers. Eventually one of those patients will maybe ‚Äî probably? ‚Äî come to a member of one of the Alliance‚Äôs organizations, forcing the doctor to participate in providing an abortion, even if only tangentially. The organizations themselves were also directly harmed by the FDA‚Äôs approval of mifepristone, she argued, because they were forced to divert resources from their other anti-abortion priorities and to instead channel them into fighting against the FDA and commissioning studies claiming mifepristone is a deadly drug. Hawley also leaned into the argument that the zombie law from 1873 known as the Comstock Act, which forbids the mailing of ‚Äúevery article or thing‚Äù that could be used for abortion, bars the freer distribution of mifepristone. Mifepristone, she noted, certainly fits in the category of banned items. In its 9-0 opinion, the court was mum on the Comstock question. Somewhat surprisingly, Justice Clarence Thomas did not mention it in his concurring opinion either, after having referenced it during oral arguments, as did Justice Samuel Alito. Instead, the court focused on Alliance‚Äôs standing arguments ‚Äî and dismissed the case on those grounds. The organizations that make up the Alliance had not shown any concrete injury from the FDA‚Äôs approval, and it ‚Äúcannot spend its way into standing simply by expending money to gather information and advocate against the defendant‚Äôs action,‚Äù Kavanaugh wrote. ‚ÄúAn organization cannot manufacture its own standing in that way.‚Äù The court also readily dismissed the notion that any of the individual doctors had standing to sue. Their arguments were too speculative and tenuous to hit the mark. ‚ÄúBecause the plaintiffs do not prescribe, manufacture, sell, or advertise mifepristone or sponsor a competing drug, the plaintiffs suffer no directly monetary injuries from the FDA‚Äôs actions relaxing regulation of mifepristone,‚Äù Kavanaugh wrote. ‚ÄúBecause the plaintiffs do not use mifepristone, they obviously can suffer no physical injuries from FDA‚Äôs actions relaxing regulation of mifepristone.‚Äù Notably, the court‚Äôs opinion nodded to mifepristone‚Äôs safety by acknowledging that the plaintiffs presented no evidence suggesting that the FDA‚Äôs actions both increased the number of patients seeking them out for treatment and caused them to divert attention from other patients. Nor have they identified ‚Äúany instances‚Äù from the past where they were sued or where their insurance costs increased because they‚Äôd treated pregnant patients ‚Äúsuffering mifepristone complications,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúNor have the plaintiffs offered any persuasive evidence or reason to believe that the future will be different.‚Äù The case now goes back to the 5th Circuit, with a mandate to follow the high court‚Äôs ruling. Join The Conversation

organizations.name: fighting medication abortion after supreme court
fda v. alliance for hippocratic medicine

author: University of Utah Health
title: New Addiction Treatment Research Receives Major Funding
text: Newswise ‚Äî Worldwide, someone dies from drug or alcohol addiction every four minutes. Now, researchers at Huntsman Mental Health Institute at the University of Utah have been selected by Wellcome Leap to research a new treatment for substance use disorder as part of a $50 million commitment to develop innovative treatments. Brian J. Mickey, MD, PhD, professor of psychiatry at Huntsman Mental Health Institute, will lead the team of investigators with expertise in psychiatry, biomedical engineering, neuroscience, radiology, and social work to research a new, noninvasive treatment for addiction. Co-principal investigators include Jan Kubanek, PhD and Taylor Webb, PhD ; co-investigators include Eric Garland, PhD, LCSW ; Rana Jawish, MD ; Vincent Koppelmans, PhD ; and Tom Riis, PhD. The research will be funded by the Untangling Addiction program, which is a $50 million program founded by Wellcome Leap to develop scalable measures to assess addiction susceptibility, quantify the risks stemming from addiction, and develop innovative treatments. ‚ÄúSubstance use disorder is a significant global health problem, and yet the treatment options are limited,‚Äù Mickey said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre developing a non-invasive intervention for preventing and treating addiction, chronic pain, and depression. This funding will help us validate and generate the data to support the next critical step: an efficacy trial to determine the effectiveness of the intervention.‚Äù Mickey‚Äôs team will use a novel ultrasound-based device to modulate deep brain regions and behaviors associated with opioid addiction. The goal will be to ultimately develop this approach into an individually targeted therapeutic intervention for a range of addictions. ‚ÄúAddictions are brain illnesses that have enormous negative impact on individuals, families, and society,‚Äù Mickey said. ‚ÄúA major reason that addictions have been difficult to prevent‚Äîand treat‚Äîis that they are driven by dysfunction of deep brain regions that are challenging to access. Many psychiatric problems such as depression, anxiety, and addiction are caused by malfunction of brain circuits. This project is an example of our mission to understand how these neural circuits are dysregulated and to develop novel, circuit-targeted interventions that return the brain to a healthy state.‚Äù "We are proud to bring Wellcome Leap's innovative problem-solving and funding approach to our research enterprise at the University of Utah," said Taylor Randall, President , University of Utah. "To have our mental health researchers contributing to pioneering work on addiction treatment reaffirms our commitment to improving lives through discovery." ‚ÄúWhat makes research like this so impactful is that it brings together a variety of disciplines to help solve complex problems in mental health,‚Äù said Mark Hyman Rapaport, MD , CEO of Huntsman Mental Health Institute. ‚ÄúThis is particularly timely news given the groundbreaking of a new translational research building on campus focused on mental health and the brain. Our nation is in a mental health crisis, but there is hope if we can think differently and work together to change this trajectory.‚Äù # # # About Huntsman Mental Health Institute Huntsman Mental Health Institute at University of Utah Health brings together 75 years of patient care, research, and education into one of the nation's leading academic medical centers focused on mental health. Nestled in the campus of University of Utah, Huntsman Mental Health Institute serves the community with 1,600 faculty and staff in 20 locations providing inpatient and outpatient services for youth, teens, and adults as well as a comprehensive crisis care model which includes the nationally recognized SafeUT app and the 988 Crisis hotline for Utah. Our mission is to advance mental health knowledge, hope, and healing for all. Learn more at: HMHI.utah.edu and join the conversation on TikTok , X and

organizations.name: new addiction treatment research receives major funding worldwide

author: @CTVCalgary
title: July 2024 was Calgary's hottest ever recorded: ECCC | CTV News
text: Calgary experienced its hottest July on record last month, according to new data from Environment and Climate Change Canada (ECCC). The monthly mean temperature of 19.9 C was 3.4 degrees higher than the normal mark of 16.5 C for the month, ECCC shared in a post on social media. Temperature data has been kept in Calgary for 141 years. The Calgary airport was among four weather stations in Alberta that recorded their hottest July, along with Edmonton Blatchford, Grande Prairie A and High Level. ‚ÄúThe driver of these records was a couple of prolonged heat events,‚Äù ECCC said in the post. Calgary experienced eight days at or over 30 C in July, including a stretch of four straight days. The record for consecutive days over 30 C of seven was set in 1917. Grande Prairie set a new record, with a stretch of eight days over 30 C ‚Äì out of a total of 12. That broke the previous record of seven set in 1936. Edmonton (seven) and Red Deer (six) tied their previous records for consecutive days over 30 C. Meanwhile, Calgary received 41.3 millimetres of precipitation in June, down from the normal mark of 65.5 millimetres. Those marks are not record-setting though ‚Äì sitting as Calgary‚Äôs 40th driest recorded July. ‚ÄúWith the hot and dry weather, fire activity increased dramatically in July leading to days with widespread smoke across the province,‚Äù ECCC said. ‚ÄúWhile smoke hasn‚Äôt been as notable as in years past, poor air quality was still a big part of our July.‚Äù More weather information can be found on ECCC‚Äôs website .
